--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> Giuliano,

> =
Let me see if I have the situation clear:

> Using all 3.8 tests joined in =
a 3.8 AllTests suite, there are no problems.
> Using the same tests, with s=
ome converted to 4.5, joined with
> ClasspathSuite, you run out of memory.
=

Not exactly. Until a few months ago all our tests were JUnit 3.8 tests org=
anized with AllTests suite.

Then we introduced JUnit 4.5 and we started ha=
ving:
*) 3.8 suites running a mix of 3.8 & 4.5 tests
*) 4.5 suites running =
4.5 tests
I don't think we ever had 4.5 suites running 3.8 tests as well.

=
At the root of everything there were 3 main 3.8 suites. Let's call them:
*)=
 AllTestsSuite1 (related to project P1) =3D=3D> ~650 tests (mostly unit tes=
ts)
*) AllTestsSuite2 (related to project P2) =3D=3D> ~350 tests (a mix of =
unit tests and HttpUnit tests)
*) AllTestsSuite3 (related to project P3) =
=3D=3D> ~500 tests (mostly HttpUnit tests)
The 3 suites are merged together=
 in a big bang 3.8 suites, called AllSuperMegaHyperTestSuite for evident re=
asons :)

All the tests run fine with 196 MB of heap until a few days ago.
=
Every developer runs typically one of the 3 suites above, not AllSuperMegaH=
yperTestSuite, depending on which area of the system they are working on. 
=
I run AllSuperMegaHyperTestSuite from time to time. Hudson runs it with Clo=
ver every day.

Some days ago we noticed an increase in memory consumption,=
 noticeable on Hudson only. We thought that this was related more to Clover=
 than anything else.

But when we decided to get rid of 3.8 suites in P1 it=
 became very noticeable. The message on the Spring Framework forum confirme=
d my doubts: a memory leak related to 3.8 tests run by 4.5 suites. Implemen=
ting the suggested fix didn't help though.

So we have proceeded converting=
 all 3.8 tests to 4.5 in P1: the situation has improved significantly, but =
still now the tests run only with 1048 MB of heap (and 128 MB of PermGen sp=
ace). Now, I don't think that the root of the problem is necessarily in JUn=
it, but the way it holds onto instance fields in the tests doesn't help =3D=
=3D> some of our tests, especially those based on HttpUnit, have a lot of s=
tate in instance fields.

So I was wondering if this "issue" (well, whateve=
r you wanna call it) is known to you guys, if workarounds are available, et=
c.
We think of converting all 3.8 tests to 4.5 in P2 & P3 anyway. That shou=
ld help, if I'm not mistaken.

> Is that right? If so, it's certainly troub=
ling. Some questions to
> help identify a potential JUnit bug:

> 1) Do you=
 run out of memory if you use ClasspathSuite, but skip the 4.5 tests?

Well=
, right now I don't have any 3.8 tests anymore in P1. When I'll get rid of =
the suites in P2 I'll try avoiding 4.5 tests first for sure.

> 2) Do you r=
un out of memory if you replace your AllTests suite with a 4.5-style Suite?=


Haven't tried that. I suppose I can give it a shot in P2.
